dc:title: The demography of Bromus tectorum: variation in time and space ( Washington).
dc:creator: Mack R.N.
dc:description: Amplitude in the variation of recruitment, survivorship and fecundity was examined for the introduced annual grass Bromus tectorum in 3 habitat types in eastern Washington for 3 consecutive generations. Recruitment was usually concentrated in late summer and autumn, but occurred at any time until mid-May of the following year. Most of any population experienced low death risk until June, although some cohorts emerging in late summer were devastated (Deevey Type III curve) during periods of drought or extended snow cover. Most plants survived to produce seed. Loss of seed production from devastated autumn-emergent plants was offset by the reproduction of late winter-spring recruits. B. tectorum persists under the vagaries of steppe environments by its ability to behave simultaneously on the same site as an ephemeral monocarpic, annual monocarpic and winter annual monocarpic species. Year-to-year variation in weather and predator activity overrode the intrinsic differences along a 200km transect of varying moisture availability often producing considerable amplitude in population attributes (recruitment, survivorship and fecundity). Characterization of any species as a colonizer, etc., on the basis of life history traits alone may be erroneous; knowledge of the variation in such population attributes is also necessary.-Authors

dc:title: Female predominant sex ratios and physiological differentiation in arctic willows.
dc:creator: Crawford R.M.M.
dc:description: A survey of plants in flower of Salix polaris in Spitsbergen and S. herbacea in Iceland revealed in both species similar female-biased sex ratios of 59:41. The similarity of the degree of (non-random) female predominance in S. polaris and S. herbacea suggests that there is an optimal proportion and a common mechanism for the excess of female over male plants. A possible control mechanism is discussed where the advantage gained from increased seed production due to an excess of female plants is progressively reduced as the effective poulation size diminishes with the departure of the sex ratio from equality.-from Authors

dc:title: Plant geometry and self-thinning.
dc:creator: Lonsdale W.
dc:description: Monocultures of Agrostemma githago, Cichorium endivium and Festuca pratensis were grown at high densities. Whilst populations of all three species followed the -3/2 power law when weight was plotted against density on logarithmic scales, the intercepts were different and fell in the order Festuca > Agrostemma > Cichorium. These differences are related to plant geometry. The mean volume of canopy available to each plant was also related to density by the -3/2 power law. However, the intercepts for a number of species on a volume-density plot on logarithmic scales all fell within one order of magnitude in comparison with 2 orders of magnitude on a weight-density plot. The biomass which could be packed into a given volume of space generally increased with canopy height, but the range was nevertheless relatively narrow (1.5-5.2 kg m-3) for the 3 species. Only part of the variation in intercept between species on a weight-density plot could be related to differences in biomass packing. Variation in the biomass per unit volume through time means that the gradient of the thinning line on a weight-density plot may be different to that on a volume plot. The -3/2 power law might be better stated in terms of canopy volume rather than weight.-from Authors

dc:title: Phytoplankton production and winter mixing: contrasting effects in two oligotrophic lakes.
dc:creator: Vincent W.
dc:description: Lake Waikaremoana, North Island, New Zealand, followed, in its thermal stratification, the classic pattern for temperate warm-monomictic lakes. During winter circulation, light availability to the phytoplankton was reduced by a factor of at least 13 relative to that in spring and summer, and there was no increased supply of P. Concentrations of algal biomass and algal production rates were low, but rose rapidly with increased irradiance in spring. Lake Taupo experienced similar thermal stratification and mixing, but concentrations of algal biomass and algal photosynthetic production rose to maxima for the year during winter isothermy when temperatures were at their annual minimum and when mixing extended to the bottom of the lake. Winter circulation brought an increased supply of P, and N which later controlled the amount of algal growth in the euphotic zone. This increased availability of potentially limiting nutrients offset the effects of low light availability and low temperature. Lake Taupo, and other nearby lakes which behave similarly, form intermediates between temperate lakes with typical winter minima of algal production and many tropical lakes which experience maximum phytoplankton production during storm-induced mixing.-from Author

dc:title: Germination ecology of Veronica arvensis.
dc:creator: Baskin J.
dc:description: A high proportion of the freshly-matured seeds of Veronica arvensis were dormant at maturity in late May. During the summer after-ripening period, the proportion and the rate of germination increased, and the range of temperature at which seeds could germinate widened. Seeds required light for germination, and they germinated equally well at constant and alternating temperatures, but none germinated at 25oC or at the simulated August field temperature regime of 35/20oC. Seeds in an unheated glasshouse on soil kept at field capacity and on soil that was alternately wetted and dried during summer had a low germination; 3 and 1%, respectively, in the 1st summer after planting, and none during the 2nd and 3rd summers. This lack of germination during the summer was probably because the temperature was above that required for germination. By September and October the temperature in the field has fallen sufficiently to allow a high proportion of the seeds to germinate if light and soil moisture are adequate. Seeds that do not germinate during the 1st autumn after dispersal may germinate during the following spring or in some subsequent autumn or spring. -from Authors

dc:title: Ecological studies in four contrasting lowland rain forests in Gunung Mulu National Park, Sarawak. I. Forest environment, structure and floristics.
dc:creator: Proctor J.
dc:description: Sites of 1 ha were established in each of 4 contrasting types of primary lowland rain forest: alluvial forest (AF); dipterocarp forest (DF); heath forest (HF) and forest over limestone (LF). The total above-ground forest biomass (t ha-1 dry weight) was calculated as: AF,250; DF,650; HF,470; LF,380. There were at least 223 species ha-1 in the AF; 214 in the DF; 123 in the HF; and 78 in the LF. The AF soil was heterogenous, with gley soils of high base status in the lower, occasionally flooded, part and podzols and peats in the higher part. The DF soil was acid and very low in Ca. It was lower in total exchangeable bases than the very acid podzolic soils of the HF. The LF soils were shallow, highly organic, of high base status, and neutral to mildly acid pH. The species-rich DF occurred on very poor soils but there was no simple relationship between soil nutrient element concentrations and biomass of species richness. The causes of the distinctive sclerophyllous leaves of the heath forest are discussed. Extreme soil acidity in the organic soils may limit N-mineralization and low levels of biologically active nitrogen favour sclerophylly. Features of heat forest which reduce transpiration may be important in reducing the mass flow of soil toxins to the root surfaces.-from Authors English

dc:title: Nutrient use by evergreen and deciduous shrubs in southern California. I. Community nutrient cycling and nutrient-use efficiency.
dc:creator: Gray J.
dc:description: The chaparral was a pure stand of the evergreen shrub Ceanothus megacarpus; the coastal sage was co-dominated by the drought-deciduous shrubs Salvia leucophylla and Artemisia californica. Above-ground nutrient pools, annual accumulation, and annual return were greater in the chaparral. Foliar nutrient concentrations were greater and more variable in the drought-deciduous shrubs than in Ceanothus. In the non-flowering year, there was luxury consumption of N, P and K in the leaves of Ceanothus, in which excess nutrients were accumulated in leaves during growth and translocated to the stems and roots later. The leaves of Artemisia and Salvia had a greater susceptibility to the loss of elements by leaching. Throughfall and stemflow losses were proportionately greater in the coastal sage scrub than in the chaparral during winter. Nutrient-use efficiency was higher in the chaparral for all major elements. Annual nutrient turnover was lower in the chaparral than in the coastal sage scrub. Nutrient use by the Ceanothus was comparatively self-regulated and conservative, suggesting that its growth may be less dependent upon soil nutrient availability on both a seasonal and annual basis compared with deciduous shrubs.-from Author

dc:title: Nutrient use by evergreen and deciduous shrubs in southern California. II. Experimental investigations of the relationship between growth, nitrogen uptake and nitrogen availability.
dc:creator: Gray J.
dc:description: Experiments were conducted to test the hypothesis that growth of the drought-deciduous shrub, Salvia leucophylla is more closely coupled to soil N availability than growth of the evergreen chaparral shrub, Ceanothus megacarpus. Seedlings were grown in sand culture for 50 days. Salvia had a greater relative growth rate, dry matter yield, leaf area, and concentration of N in its tissues than Ceanothus. Salvia also exhibited a linear response to increasing N concentration in terms of yield, leaf area, N content, and root absorption rate, whereas Ceanothus showed an asymptotic response to increasing N concentration. Salvia showed a greater response during recovery from N stress and when supplied with a N flush, in terms of growth rate, N concentration, and root absorption rates. Its responsive, opportunistic pattern of growth and nutrient uptake appear to be adaptive to the nutrient conditions in the coastal sage scrub, the community in which it is common. The limited response of Ceanothus to varying N concentration suggests an uncoupling of growth from N availability.-from Authors

dc:title: Element nutrition of two contrasted dune annuals.
dc:creator: Ernst W.
dc:description: Biomass and nutrient-element allocation of Erodium glutinosum and Phleum arenarium were analysed during complete life cycles. Both had high translocation rates of N and P from ageing vegetative tissue to fruits. Nutrient surpluses increased the period of vegetative growth of P. arenarium but shortened that of E. glutinosum. Results are discussed in relation to niche differentiation, efficiency of nutrient use and the interaction between water and nutrient supplies.-from Author Erodium glutinosum Phleum arenarium

dc:title: Studies in the vegetational history of the northern Pennines. III. Variations in the composition of the mid- Flandrian forests.
dc:creator: Turner J.
dc:description: Data on frequencies of pollen grains in peat have been collected from 38 sites in the northern Pennines, northern England for the period corresponding to pollen assemblage zone VIIa or Flandrian II. Temporal variations in pollen frequencies reflect the well-documented course of Flandrian forest history. Most of the variation, however, is spatial and can be explained by differing local climatic and edaphic conditions. Most of the spatial variation relates to the composition of the forests at low altitudes on Millstone Grits in the NE of the region, which now has a particularly cloudy climate. There was more Betula, Pinus, Salix and Melampyrum, and less Ulmus and Corylus than in other parts of the region. Tilia was more abundant in the S of the region, probably because its northern extension was limited, as now, by low summer temperatures. Fraxinus was also more abundant in the S, probably owing partly to edaphic factors. Little of the variation appears to be anthropogenic, although the tendency of Fraxinus, Gramineae and Potentilla-type pollen to have high frequencies in the mid- altitude range 450-680m, could be attributed to Mesolithic hunting and burning.-from Authors

dc:title: Ecological studies in four contrasting lowland rain forests in Gunung Mulu National Park, Sarawak. II. Litterfall, litter standing crop and preliminary observations on herbivory.
dc:creator: Proctor J.
dc:description: Small litterfall (leaves, wood = or <2cm diameter, reproductive parts, and trash) was compared on sites of 1 ha in each of 4 types of lowland forest. The total small litterfall was (t ha-1yr-1 + or - 95% confidence limits): for alluvial forest (AF), 11.5 + or - 1.9; dipterocarp forest (DF), 8.8 + or - 0.6; heath forest (HF), 9.2 + or - 1.2; and limestone-site forest (LF), 12.0 + or - 1.3. A peak of litterfall occurred on all sites during a May-June period of high rainfall before the driest time of the year. The low Ca concentration in the DF litterfall and low nitrogen in the KF litterfall were notable. Total polyphenol concentrations in the leaf litterfall were ranked HF>LF>DF>AF. Virtually no wood >10cm diameter fell in the collection quadrats. Results for the >2cm-= or <10cm diameter wood were ranked AF>HF>LF>DF. Small-litter standing crop lowest value was 4.7 t ha-1 in the AF in March 1978, the highest 7.5 t ha-1 in the LF in February 1978. There were large differences between the 4 forests in the annual addition of elements in litterfall and in the element contents of small-litter standing crop and soils. There were several examples of high litterfall content/soil pool quotients. The highest quotient (2.8) was for Ca in the DF, an extreme example of rapid cycling of a deficient element in a rain forest.-from Authors

dc:title: Selection of seedlings of Thymus vulgaris by grazing slugs ( Agriolimax reticulatus).
dc:creator: Gouyon P.
dc:description: Different terpene compositions provide very different defences by thyme against slugs Agriolimax reticulatus. The behaviour of an individual slug is determined by several factors, including the past experience of the animal.-from Authors

dc:title: A quantitative method for stratigraphic analysis of bryophytes in Holocene peat.
dc:creator: Janssens J.A.
dc:description: A 3.8m deep peat core was analysed from Red Lake Peatland, on the bed of Glacial Lake Agassiz, northern Minnesota. Peat accumulation began at this site c.3500 yr BP. Scorpidium scorpioides and Calliergon trifarium are the major peat formers during several recurring episodes of peat accumulation. Seven other species of the Ambylstegiaceae are recorded. One or more of 6 Sphagnum species dominate other periods of the accumulation. Four additional types belong to the Bryaceae, Meesiaceae, Aulacomniaceae and Polytrichaceae. Five local bryophyte zones are sharply delimited in the late Holocene peat of this site. The 4 lower zones reflect either changes in the water level in a non-patterned fen system or fluctuations in the size of low hummocks formed by emergent, minerotrophic bryophytes in a patterned fen. The uppermost zone indicates the formation of less minerotrophic vegetation on top of the fen peat and periodic advances of the bog margin over the fen at the coring site.-from Author

dc:title: Silicon consumption and population density changes of dominant planktonic diatoms in Lake Constance.
dc:creator: Sommer U.
dc:description: Concentration of dissolved reactive Si decreased markedly during the spring and summer growth period of diatoms in 1979 and 1980. The silicon to cell quotient (mg per million cells) varied over a wide range from 0.005 for Stephanodiscus hantzschii to 0.72 for Synedra acus, while that of silicon per unit cell volume (mg mm-3) varied over a narrower range from 0.10 for Stephanodiscus hantzschii and Fragilaria crotonesis to 0.36 for Synedra acus. A four-compartment model, that allows estimates of the rates of growth and of loss of diatom populations to be calculated, is outlined. Summer succession from Asterionella formosa to either F. crotonensis (1979) or Stephanodiscus binderanus (1980) is explained by interspecific differences in the effects of silicon concentration on growth and death. For A. formosa, Si depletion did not stop cell-division but led to the death of most of the population. For F. crotonensis and Stephanodiscus binderanus cell division stopped but cells did not die and population growth continued after the concentration of dissolved silicon had increased again.-from Authors

dc:title: Effects of organic matter additions to sediment on the growth of aquatic plants.
dc:creator: Barko J.
dc:description: Growth of three completely submerged species (Elodea canadensis, Hydrilla verticillata, Myriophyllum spicatum) and 3 partly emergent species (Myriophyllum aquaticum, Potamogeton nodosus, Sagittaria latifolia) was examined on a control sediment and on the same sediment to which different types of plant organic matter (2 labile, 3 refractory) had been added. With addition of 5% organic matter, growth of emergent species was generally less inhibited than that of submerged species on sediment. With greater additions of organic matter, growth of both H. verticillata and P. nodosus was severely inhibited irrespective of the nature of the addition. Growth was unrelated to concentration of Fe, Mn or PO4 in the interstitial water of sediments, but there was possible N limitation of growth on sediment receiving refractory organic matter. Growth of all species was negatively correlated with mean dissolved organic carbon concentration in the interstitial water of the sediments. Growth inhibition may have resulted from the accumulation of toxic, soluble organic carbon compounds during anaerobic decomposition. The lesser inhibition of emergent plants compared with submerged plants may have been due to the greater rhizosphere-oxidizing abilities of the former.-from Authors

dc:title: Life histories of tillers of Eriophorum vaginatum in relation to tundra disturbance.
dc:creator: Fetcher N.
dc:description: Tiller survival was lower in disturbed than in undisturbed tundra, and daughter tillers were produced sooner. Addition of nutrients (as fertilizer) produced no change in tiller survival and in the age distribution of daughter tiller production in the first year following fertilization. The shapes of the survival curves were intermediate between Deevey Type I and Deevey Type II curves. The generation time for tillers in undisturbed tundra was 5.3 yr - about twice as long as in disturbed tundra - while the annual rate of increase of tillers did not differ greatly. Fertilization produced large increases in the annual rate of increase, but generation time was shortened only slightly. Reproductive values (the expected number of daughter tillers from tillers of a given age relative to the expected number from a tiller aged 0) fell into one of 3 patterns: 1) decline from maximum value at age 0; 2) increase from age 0 followed by a monotonic decline; 3) increase from age 0 followed by a gradual, irregular decline and a plateau in the older age classes. The peak in reproductive value for patterns 2) and 3) occurred 2-4 yr after the onset of tillering at age 1 or 2 yr; this is attributed to increases in age-specific tillering rate with tiller age. Sensitivity of the annual rate of increase to changes in tillering rate and survival declines with age.-from Authors

dc:title: Some relationships between environmental reliability and seed dormancy in desert annual plants.
dc:creator: Freas K.E.
dc:description: There are 2 groups of annual species that grow in the northern Chihuahuan Desert of North America. Plants either germinate and complete their life cycle in late summer, or germinate in winter or early spring and complete their life cycle in spring. The later summer season is characterized by abundant and reliable rain, while the winter-spring season has less abundant and less reliable rain. Theoretical models predict that annual plants from uncertain environments may or may not have evolved innate dormancy to offset the possibility of population extinction due to complete germination followed by complete mortality under severely unfavourable conditions. These models are tested. A summer annual species Pectis angustifolia did not have a genetically fixed innate dormancy, but 2 winter annual species (Lappula redowskii, Lepidium lasiocarpum) apparently evolved a genetically controlled innate dormancy. All three annual species exhibited environmentally-controlled seed dormancy with respect to amount of rainfall. Seeds germinated only when the equivalent of >10mm of rain fell. Above 15mm of simulated rain, germination was positively correlated with increasing amount of rain in all three species. The importance of innate dormancy, water-controlled dormancy, and seed dispersal to the long-term survival of these species is discussed.-from Authors

dc:title: Changes in two high altitude blanket bogs after the cessation of sheep grazing.
dc:creator: Rawes M.
dc:description: A 15-yr study on the effects of excluding sheep from 350m2 fenced areas on 2 high-altitude Eriophoretum blanket bogs has been carried out on Moor House National Nature Reserve, Cumbria. The bogs were species-poor, of little cover, and erosion was active. After 14-yr protection both bogs had undergone major changes in species composition, pattern of vegetation and structure. Calluna vulgaris, from an early position of scarcity, grew to dominate parts of each exclosure, whilst the cover of Empetrum nigrum trebled in the same period. However, E. nigrum, after having dominated >10% of each bog in the mid-term of the study, finally gave way to Calluna. Rubus chamaemorus and Narthecium ossifragum (the latter present only in one exclosure) increased spectacularly, but Trichophorum cespitosum became intermingled in the developing vegetation and lost its distinctive homogeneous community pattern. Leafy liverworts, in particular Diplophyllum albicans, a constant of the high-level Eriophoretum facies, declined; the colonization of bare peat was slow. Botanical composition, structure and density altered in the direction of Calluneto-Eriophoretum, a move recommended as an improvement for wildlife and possibly agriculture.-from Author

dc:title: Influences of climate and heavy metal concentrations in the soil on plants of grassland and flush vegetation in Upper Teesdale
dc:creator: Waughman G.
dc:description: Experiments were carried out in cold frames with Tofieldietalia and Brometalia erecti vegetation growing on metalliferous and non-metalliferous soils in Upper Teesdale. Barley was also grown in pots of the two soil types in cold and in mild microclimates. Leaves of barley grown on metalliferous soil in a cold microclimate contained much greater concentrations of Zn, Cd, Pb and Al than leaves of plants grown on the same soil but in a mild microclimate. These differences were not found in plants grown on non-metalliferous soil. Vegetation growth was greater in the cold frames than outside them. This climate-induced increase was significantly greater for vegetation growing on metalliferous soil than for the vegetation on non-metalliferous soil. The vegetation outside the cold frame generally had greater concentrations of heavy metals(especially Zn and Pb) than vegetation growing inside the frames; there were, generally, no such differences with nutrient elements. The effect of climate-induced increase in growth on the concentration of different elements in the aerial vegetation was examined by ranking the element-concentration-quotients (cool climate/warm climate). The greatest impact of milder microclimates was in reducing the concentrations of Cd, Zn, Pb and Al; the least impact was on concentrations of Ca, K, Mg and P; effects on Fe and Mn were intermediate. The results support the contention that in certain communities, rich in 'Teesdale rarities', the metal-rich soil may exacerbate the effect of the cold climate to reduce productivity of the vegetation as a whole to below 150 kg m-2 year-1, the suggested upper value of net growth for indefinite survival of the 'rarities'.

dc:title: Limiting nutrients for plant growth in coastal sand dune soils.
dc:creator: Kachi N.
dc:description: Oenothera erythrosepala grown in pot culture were deficient in P rather than N and K, while plants grown in the field were deficient in N rather than P and K. Incubation of dune sands resulted in increased availability of N and decreased availability of P. The low supply of inorganic N in the field is probably attributable to restriction of mineralization and nitrification and to leaching of nitrate.-from Authors

dc:title: Factors affecting the distribution of tree species in a dry zone montane forest in Sri Lanka.
dc:creator: Jayasuriya A.
dc:description: Ordination showed that most vegetational variation is related to the degree of exposure to wind, with edaphic and micro-climatic differences being responsible partly for heterogeneity between habitats. Pattern analysis of saplings of Cleistanthus pallidus, C. patulus and Eugenia rotundata showed one scale of pattern, at a block size of 8-16 m, which is related to the restricted dispersal of seeds; mature plants showed no significant departure from a random distribution. The high density pattern of saplings disappears as plants grow older owing, presumably, to density-dependent mortality. The hill range provides an altitudinal range of environments, simulating a zonation from dry to humid climates and supporting a large number of species which are otherwise distributed over a vast area with diverse climates. -from Authors

dc:title: Pollination of Orchis caspia - a nectarless plant which deceives the pollinators of nectariferous species from other plant families.
dc:creator: Dafni A.
dc:description: Orchis caspia, which provides no reward for pollination, exploits inconsistency in the behaviour of several species of bees (Anthophora sp., Eucera clypeata, E. nigrifacies, Melecta mediterranea), the legitimate pollinators of some nectariferous species (Asphodelus microcarpus, Bellevalia flexuosa, Salvia fruticosa). The bees are deceived through their low ability to discriminate O. caspia from the nectariferous species. Orchis caspia shares pollinators with O. israelitica and this may lead to formation of hybrids between the 2 species. -from Author

dc:title: Early succession on cleared forest land in Ghana.
dc:creator: Swaine M.D.
dc:description: Two categories of secondary species are defined: 1) small pioneer species - short-lived, and unable to germinate in shade; 2) large pioneer species - large trees also found in mature forest, but unable to germinate in shade. Primary, or late seral, species are capable of germination and establishment in shade. Tree density reached 2.5 trees m-2 within 1 yr, 95% of which were secondary species. Thereafter, density declined exponentially, principally by the death of secondary species, to c1 tree m-2 after 5 yr. Mortality amongst secondary species varied between 14-59% annually, but there was no evidence that the rate was lower for the large pioneers. Occurrence of large pioneer species in mature forest may reflect persistence of rapid growth, rather than extended life- span. Over 90% of the accession of secondary species during the 5-yr period was achieved in the first year, compared with c60% for primary species. At 5 yr, the number of secondary tree species was declining, whilst 1-2 additional primary species were continuing to appear each year. The immigration of new primary species other than trees was much faster - c10 species a year. Immigrant individuals were about equally divided between those germinating from the seed bank in soil and those which dispersed in by wind at the time of clearance. Total species diversity exceeded that of nearby mature forest after only 3 yr, and was c25% higher at 5 yr. -from Authors

dc:title: The population biology of plants with clonal growth. II. The nutrient strategy and modular physiology of Carex arenaria.
dc:creator: Noble J.
dc:description: The distribution of locally applied N within clones of Carex arenaria was studied in a dune system in North Wales, and in a glasshouse. Highest shoot density and plant N concentration were found in the mature phase of the clone. In all growth phases the live aerial shoots contained a higher concentration of N than dead shoots, rhizomes and roots and the concentration in aerial shoots declined from the juvenile and mature phases of development to the senile phase. Glasshouse experiments demonstrated the capacity of C. arenaria to transport nitrogen and 33P in an apical direction as the rhizome axes extended. The pattern of growth of C. arenaria results in a migratory phenotype with the capacity for continual exploration for places with locally high concentrations of scarce nutrients, and the ability to exploit such places was found.-from Authors

dc:title: Ground water and the evolution of patterned mires, Glacial Lake Agassiz peatlands, northern Minnesota.
dc:creator: Siegel D.
dc:description: Most ground-water flow is probably caused by the development and persistence of large raised bogs, and occurs because of ground- water mounds (elevated water tables) under the bogs. Lateral bog growth may be limited by the neutralizing of bog water acidity by ground-water discharge at raised bog margins.-from Author

dc:title: Demography of two natural populations of musk thistle ( Carduus nutans).
dc:creator: Lee J.
dc:description: Three life-cycle patterns were observed: winter annual, spring biennial and autumn biennial. Greatest mortality occurred in summer and late spring. There were significant differences between the populations in the time of germination, mortality, rosette growth rates, time to flowering, and seed production. Generally cohorts that germinated after autumn 1975 were slower growing, had higher rates of mortality, took longer to flower and produced fewer seeds per individual. The autumn 1975 cohort was divided into September, October and November germination cohorts. The October and November cohorts had lower rosette growth rates, lower survivorship, flowered later and produced fewer seeds per individual. Survivorship, flowering and seed production were all closely associated with rosette size. Larger plants were more likely to survive and to flower, and they produced more seed. Early autumn germination with competition-free growth favours high survivorship and early flowering. Variation in the demography of musk thistle can best be explained by phenotypic plasticity.-from Authors

dc:title: Reproductive allocation in annual and perennial species of the submerged aquatic halophyte Ruppia.
dc:creator: Brock M.
dc:description: One perennial species, R. megacarpa, and 2 annual species R. tuberosa and R. polycarpa, were studied in SE South Australia. The proportion of plant dry weight allocated to reproduction, both sexual (seeds, flowers, fruit parts) and asexual (turions) was much greater in all seasons for the 2 annual species than for the perennial. Seeds and turions of the annuals comprised 100% of live parts (3 g m-2 for R. tuberosa, 2 g m-2 for R. polycarpa) during the 7-8 months when the lakes were dry, in contrast to the maximum allocation to reproduction of 4.5% (seeds, 10.8 g m-2) for the perennial R. megacarpa. When vegetative growth was maximal for the annuals the minimum allocation to reproduction occurred (13% (9.1 g m-2) for R. tuberosa and 5% (4.8 g m-2) for R. polycarpa). Although the annual species were similar in their total reproductive effort they showed differences in the distribution of this effort between asexual and sexual reproductive units: R. tuberosa had 89% turions and 11% seeds whereas R. polycarpa had 14% turions and 86% seeds in the dry season. The monocarpic reproductive pattern, rapid development of the plants, early maturity and large amount of energy allocated to the production of a large number of small propagules are characteristic of both annual species. This contrasts markedly with the polycarpic reproductive pattern, slow plant development, late maturing and the smaller amount of energy allocation to producing a small number of large propagules in the perennial.-from Author

dc:title: Photosynthetic inorganic carbon use by freshwater plants.
dc:creator: Maberly S.
dc:description: A pH-drift technique was used to calculate free CO2 040(CO*2) and bicarbonate (HCO3-) compensation points for a range of freshwater macrophytes and phytoplankters. Variation in the 029CO*2 compensation point of Hippuris vulgaris was related to the oxygen concentration of the bathing medium, and seasonal changes in HCO3- compensation point were found in Potamogeton filiformis and in HCO3- and 029CO*2 compensation points in Elodea canadensis. The performance of these 2 macrophytes is probably affected more by seasonal changes in HCO3- compensation points than by 029CO*2 compensation points. Species showed a fairly continuous range in uptake ability with a nearly fifteen-fold difference between the most efficient (low quotient) and least efficient (high quotient) species. Although the uptake ability of macrophytes and phytoplankters overlapped, the 4 most efficient carbon extractors were phytoplankters, and the 9 least efficient were macrophytes. Anabaena cylindrica, Microcystis aeruginosa and Scenedesmus quadricauda removed >90% of the available carbon compared with 70% for the most efficient macrophytes tested (Myriophyllum spicatum, Potamogeton perfoliatus). Those species which remove 5% or less of the available carbon are taken to be unable or poorly able to use HCO3-. Such macrophytes may benefit from: 1) growing in unproductive lakes that do not experience carbon depletion; 2) seasonal access to aerial CO2; 3) high 029CO*2 concentrations in and close the sediment.- from Authors

dc:title: Interpretation of macrofossil assemblages from surface sampling of macroscopic plant remains in mire communities.
dc:creator: Greatrex P.
dc:description: Standard surface samples were collected in fen, fen-carr and swamp-carr communities. The source area of seeds was determined by measuring the distance from the sample point to the nearest mature individual of each species occurring within 5 m. The cover- abundance and reproductive performance of each species within 1 m of each sample were also recorded. The proportion of species represented by seeds varied from 50-100% and was highest in swamp-carr and lowest in fen-carr deposits. The 'seed rain' was far from even. There was a general relationship between cover-abundance and seed representation for some species (eg. Carex paniculata) but not for others (eg. Solanum dulcamara). Most seeds and fruits in the surface samples could have come from plants growing within 1 m of each sampling point. Those from greater distances are adapted for dispersal by wind or water. Reconstructions of past plant communities from the assemblages in a single sample may therefore apply only to the immediate vicinity of that sampling point.-from Author

dc:title: Regeneration of oak- birch woodland following exclusion of sheep.
dc:creator: Pigott C.
dc:description: Sheep have been excluded for 26 yr from 1.12 ha of woodland dominated by Quercus petraea, Betula pendula and B. pubescens in which there had been no regeneration of oak for at least 50 yr and only limited regeneration of birch. Inside the enclosure Deschampsia flexuosa has grown taller and Vaccinium myrtillus has greatly increased both in cover and in height. Seedlings of Betula spp. are plentiful every year in the grazed field-layer but most are rapidly destroyed; they are almost absent from the ungrazed field-layer. A proportion of those present within the enclosed area in 1955-56 have survived and are now saplings 1-4 m tall but there is no evidence of subsequent recruitment. Seedlings of Q. petraea occur both inside and outside the enclosure in years following large crops of acorns. Outside they are destroyed; inside a proportion of each crop survives to give successive recruitments to the population of saplings, and the tallest saplings are now 4-5 m high. -from Author

dc:title: Experimental ecology of Dryas octopetala ecotypes. I. Ecotypic differentiation and life-cycle stages of selection.
dc:creator: McGraw J.
dc:description: Leaf morphology was measured to assess phenotypic effects of reciprocal transplants of adults. Analysis of leaf traits suggested that greater morphological plasticity in the snowbed ecotype accounts for the bulk of the observed phenotypic differences between populations. Pollen flow was greatly reduced by separation of flowering times of the 2 ecotypes. Over 99% of pollen movement was between flowers of the same ecotype. Neither ecotype was apomictic or auto-fertile; both were self-incompatible. There were apparently no breeding system barriers to gene flow. Selection, measured as survival, favoured seedlings of the snowbed ecotype over those of the fellfield ecotype at the snowbed site (selection coefficient 0.55). At the fellfield site, selection favoured the fellfield ecotype at the adult stage (selection coefficient 0.50). Seed germination was higher and seedling survival lower at the fellfield site than at the snowbed site for both ecotypes. Therefore, the 'home' site was not always the 'better' site at all life-cycle stages; ecotypes were not perfectly matched with the environment. Selection at present acts only to give a relative advantage to native ecotypes.-from Authors

dc:title: Pattern in the simple moss-turf communities of the sub-Antarctic and maritime Antarctic.
dc:creator: Usher M.
dc:description: Grids of 1500 (300 X 5) 2 X 2 cm quadrats were recorded on 3 moss-turf sites: South Georgia in the Sub-Antarctic (3 dominant species), and in the maritime Antarctic on Signy Island (2 dominant species) and on Galindez Island (a virtual monoculture of Polytrichum alpestre). The stepped blocked quadrats variance method of pattern analysis and the two-term local quadrat variance method were used on all data. The pattern in the simplest of these communities, Galindez Island, is due to the alternation of mossy areas, or hummocks, and bare ground. At Signy Island there is a well developed pattern, with 2 scales of heterogeneity at c.20 cm and at 1.2-2.0 m. The latter is considered to be due to the history of vegetation development, which is determined by the distribution of rocks now beneath the surface of the moss carpet. The South Georgia community had 2 scales of pattern similar to those in Signy Island, but the factors determining them are unknown. On all sites, virtually all analyses indicated a small scale of pattern at c.20 cm. This scale is important when sampling both the vegetation and the animal communities living within the moss-turf communities.- from Author

dc:title: Phenological patterns of Chihuahuan desert plants in relation to the timing of water availability.
dc:creator: Kemp P.
dc:description: Annual plant species consisted of a winter-spring group containing only species with the C3 photosynthetic pathway which utilize the moisture from frontal storms of winter, and a summer group containing a large majority of species with the C4 photosynthetic pathway which utilize the moisture from convectional storms of late summer. Perennial plant species consisted of C3 and C4 forbs, C4 grasses, C3 shrubs and CAM shrubs. The C3 forbs showed greatest activity in spring or autumn while the C4 forbs and grasses were most active in the summer and autumn. The C3 shrubs and CAM shrubs were active at various times from spring to autumn and not as dependent as the other groups on available soil moisture. There was above average precipitation in late summer and autumn during the 1st year of study and an early and prolonged drought in autumn of the 2nd year. Some species of perennial C3 forbs and C4 grasses responded to the abundant precipitation of the 1st autumn with increased density or cover in the 2nd year, but there was little change in the shrub species. The drought in the 2nd year caused a reduction in the number of species and individuals of both C3 and C4 annual plants. The high species diversity in this habitat is partly a result of the different life form and photosynthetic pathway groups, each being adapted for utilizing a particular phase of the seasonally and yearly variable water. - from Author

dc:title: Compensation and regrowth in ragwort ( Senecio jacobaea) attacked by cinnabar moth ( Tyria jacobaeae).
dc:creator: Islam Z.
dc:description: The ability of ragwort to compensate for cinnabar moth larvae feeding is affected by the size of the plant; timing of attack and number of feeding larvae have rather little effect. Small plants (<20 cm rosette diameter) produce c.2500 seeds after being completely stripped of their initial set of flower heads; defoliated large plants produce >10 000 seeds. Compensation in seed production is due mainly to the production of new capitula on regrowth shoots from the root crown or from surviving parts of the primary shoot. The number of seeds per capitulum is lower under some defoliation regimes than in undefoliated plants. Seeds produced on regrowth shoots are substantially smaller than seeds produced on primary shoots. Large plants (>30 cm rosette diameter) allocate proportionately more of their biomass to reproductive tissues than do small plants; undefoliated plants allocate more than defoliated individuals. Plants do not necessarily die after flowering; they retain a food reserve in the rootstock for regrowth the following spring irrespective of their defoliation history. The overwinter death rate of plants which have flowered is only 25%. Ragwort and cinnabar moth provide what is probably the best example of non-reciprocal population regulation; the herbivore is food limited but the plant is not herbivore limited.-from Authors

dc:title: Secondary succession following slash and burn agriculture in north-eastern India. II. Nutrient cycling.
dc:creator: Toky O.
dc:description: Concentrations of N, P and K were higher in the living aerial biomass than in litter. Trees had a high concentration of Ca, a bamboo of K, and herbaceous species of P. The elements in the above-ground living biomass increased linearly with increase in the age of the fallow until, in 20-yr-old fallow, densities were (g m-2): 49, N; 6, P; 138, K; 44, Ca; and 23, Mg. In fallows 10-20 yr old, bamboo alone contained 40-50% of N, 44-49% of P, 54-60% of K 17-20% of Ca and 35-40% of Mg in the total vegetation. Annual rate of accumulation was maximal after 15-20 yr for N (2.5 g m-2 yr-1), 10-15 yr for K (8.1 g m-2 yr-1) , and during the 1st year for P (0.4 g m-2 yr-1). Potassium showed the highest rate of accumulation in different fallows and was 2.5- to 4.5-fold higher than Ca and 3- to 14-fold higher than Mg. Density of elements in the soil was minimal in 5-10-yr-old fallows. The annual return of elements through litterfall increased with the age of the fallow during the 20 yr of study. -from Authors

dc:title: Significance of small species of Chlorophyta in freshwater phytoplankton communities with special reference to five Welsh lakes.
dc:creator: Priddle J.
dc:description: The small Chlorophyta included both motile and non-motile species of Chlorococcales and Volvocales. Ankistrodesmus falcatus was the most cosmopolitan species and occasionally exceeded 103 cm-3 in all lakes. Chlorella minutissima, C. vulgaris and Scenedesmus graheinsii also occurred in all lakes. Some small species of Chlamydomonas and Chloromonas were restricted to 1 or 2 of the lakes. The mountain lakes in Snowdonia had nutrient-poor waters supporting phytoplankton populations of low density. Small Chlorophyta were dominant numerically and were present throughout the year. Median proportions of numbers of small Chlorophyta of the total number of all other phytoplankton taxa were 87% and 91% for Llyn Cwellyn and Llyn Llydaw, respectively. Llyn Padarn, a mesotrophic lake, had a greater phytoplankton biomass. Phytoplankton showed distinct seasonal periodicity, with the spring diatom growth followed by a population of Oscillatoria limnetica during summer, and further diatom growth in autumn. Small Chlorophyta were present through the year with population densities >104 cm-3 during summer; the median proportion of the total number of all phytoplankton taxa was 70%. Llyn Coron and Llyn Maelog, in agricultural catchments on Anglesey, were nutrient-rich. The succession of phytoplankton was dominated by taxa of larger-celled algae, mainly diatoms and buoyant blue-green algae. Phytoplankton density was >100 mg m-3 during spring and summer. Small Chlorophyta reached maximum population densities, >103 organisms cm-3, during winter and early spring. During summer the standing crop density of planktonic small Chlorophyta was low in these eutrophic lakes.-from Authors Ankistrodesmus falcatus Chlorella minutissima Chlorella vulgaris Chlamydomonas Chloromonas Oscillatoria limnetica Chlorococcales Volvocales Llyn Cwellyn Llyn Llydaw Llyn Padarn Llyn Coron Llyn Maelog.

dc:title: Forest and moorland in the south Pennine uplands in the mid- Flandrian period. I. Macrofossil evidence of the former forest cover.
dc:creator: Tallis J.
dc:description: Buried tree remains were detected at 53 localities; pine Pinus and birch Betula were the commonest species, but willow Salix and oak Quercus were also frequent. Tree remains were recorded in the mineral soil below the peat, at the peat-soil interface, embedded 10-30 cm above the peat base, or embedded half-way up the peat profile. At several sites, 2 or 3 superposed layers of different tree species occurred. Most tree remains occurred in the shallower marginal peats, and <520 m altitude. However, sparse remains were recorded at altitudes up to 610 m (willow), and at the base of peat deposits up to 4.1 m deep. Radiocarbon datings showed 3 groups of dates within the period 7676-3995 yr BP (<7000, 5410-4495 and 4340-3995 yr BP), and a single date of 1350 yr BP. -from Authors

dc:title: Demography of Floerkea proserpinacoides, a forest floor annual. I. Density-dependent growth and mortality.
dc:creator: Smith B.
dc:description: Floerkea proserpinacoides (Limnanthaceae) is a spring ephemeral annual plant of mesic North American deciduous forests that typically grows at high density. Survivorship curves of plants were of similar shape at different densities, but plants at high density died sooner than did those at low density. Birth rates of nodes and leaflets decreased sooner at progressively higher density. The result was a significant density-dependent trend in the production per plant of these parts. Production of buds and branches was also significantly smaller at high density, but the phenologies of bud and branch production did not differ with density. The number of nodes produced per plant is the product of bud production per plant, shoot production per bud, and node production per shoot. All were negatively affected by density, but node production per shoot was influenced most. Processes initiated later are those most affected by crowding. Bud behaviour and branch structure varied significantly according to their node-position on the plant. -from Author

dc:title: The use of contact sampling in studies of association in vegetation.
dc:creator: De Jong P.
dc:description: It is preferable to tabulate and analyse data with an unfolded contingency table where the ordered 'contact pairs' (i, j) and (j, i) are distinguished, rather than with a folded (triangular) table used previously. This, together with considerations of the treatment of data in which there are events of within-species 'contact pairs' (i.e. when j = i), forms the basis for recommending an 'optimal' strategy for examining tendencies for between-species association - optimal in the sense of both statistical efficacy and sampling mechanics. -from Authors

dc:title: Demography of Floerkea proserpinacoides, a forest floor annual. III. Dynamics of seed and seedling populations.
dc:creator: Smith B.
dc:description: Floerkea proserpinacoides (Limnanthaceae) is a spring-ephemeral forest-floor annual. An adult is usually prostrate when its seeds are shed, so the primary initial dispersal agent is the shoot itself (mean distance from seed to parent root system was c10 cm). Between 88-97% of the seed bank germinated each year, and only 1-3% of seeds decayed. Predation on seeds was very low. The fraction remaining dormant after a yr, though small, varied significantly between years. Neither seed density nor species composition of the leaf litter affected behaviour of the seed bank. Mortality increased as the seedlings grew through the leaf litter on the forest floor, but a seedling had a better chance of emerging if it was a member of a dense rather than a sparse seedling population because dense populations could collectively push aside litter. -from Author

dc:title: Seed dispersal of the tropical tree, Platypodium elegans, and the escape of its seedlings from fungal pathogens.
dc:creator: Augspurger C.
dc:description: Seedlings of Platypodium elegans, a wind-dispersed tree on Barro Colorado Island, Panama, were monitored. Damping-off by fungi caused most mortality in the first 3 months, during which mortality occurred at an exponential rate. Both incidence and rate of damping-off were inversely correlated with distance of seedlings from the parent tree. Irrespective of density, a lower proportion of seedlings died from damping-off in light-gaps than in the shaded understory. After 1 yr a higher proportion and absolute number of seedlings survived at distances away from the parent; survival was highest in light-gaps. Fungal pathogens causing damping-off may increase selection for the dispersal of seeds away from the parent tree. They significantly increase the distance at which a parent's offspring are likely to survive the seedling stage and thus, ultimately, may influence tree spatial patterns and species diversity of the tropical forest. -from Author

dc:title: Interspecific competition and niche differentiation between Plantago lanceolata and Anthoxanthum odoratum in a natural hayfield.
dc:creator: Berendse F.
dc:description: There was strong intraspecific competition within the populations of both species at the densities in which they occurred. In mixed plots Anthoxanthum odoratum was less negatively influenced by interspecific competition than by competition with other A. odoratum individuals, and Plantago lanceolata was not affected by interspecific competition with A. odoratum. The relative yield total (the sum of yields per species in mixed culture divided by yields in monoculture) reached values of c1.5, which indicated a high degree of niche differentiation. During the 2 yr of observation an equilibrium between the two species was established. In undisturbed vegetation, the biomass of P. lanceolata decreased greatly after addition of nutrients. In plots from which other plant species had been removed, fertilization led to an increase in P. lanceolata biomass. Decline of P. lanceolata (and probably of other dicotyledons) after fertilizer application may be caused by an increase in the intensity of interspecific competition. -from Author

dc:title: Demographic and genetic changes in populations of Echium plantagineum.
dc:creator: Burdon J.
dc:description: Seven separate cohorts germinated over 6 months. All had very high seedling mortality, with the total number of individuals being reduced from 1491 to 95 by the end of the season. Genetic changes in the same population were determined by electrophoretic analysis. Evidence was obtained for significant changes in the frequency of certain alleles and for increased survival of individuals heterozygous at either the Pgi or Pgm loci. The relative competitive abilities of the common blue-purple-flowered form of E. plantagineum and of a rare pure white form, were assessed. White flowered individuals were consistently the poorer competitors.-from Authors

dc:title: Variations in the demography of natural populations of the wild strawberries Fragaria vesca and F. virginiana.
dc:creator: Angevine M.
dc:description: Ramet densities varied greatly among the sites, from 1.8-340 m2. Mean size of ramets differed significantly among the sites, as did the relationship between size and age; in F. vesca populations, older ramets were larger; in F. virginiana populations they were not. The patterns of age-specific mortality fell into 2 groups: sites where newly-produced ramets were subject to the same risk as established adults; and sites where newly-produced ramets had 5-10 times greater risk. Survivorship within cohorts was logarithmic with time. Cyclic annual variation in mortality rate was marked (and synchronous across cohorts) in some sites, but absent in others. The probabilities of flowering and producing stolons differed significantly among sites and between years. The number of flowers, fruits, stolons or rooted nodes produced per reproductive individual did not differ, however. The two species cannot easily be characterized by the demographic parameters measured. The recent history of each site seemed to influence local demography more than taxonomic identity.-from Author

dc:title: Population biology of an annual plant in a temporarily variable habitat.
dc:creator: Klemow K.
dc:description: A population of the summer annual Erucastrum gallicum (Brassicaceae) colonizing an abandoned limestone quarry near Syracuse, New York, was monitored for 5 consecutive years. Survival and percentage reproduction of plants that emerged in the spring varied markedly depending upon rainfall. Deevey survivorship curves, Types I, II, and III were observed in cohorts from a year with abundant rainfall, a year with intermittent rainfall and drought, and a year with spring drought, respectively. Growth and the number of seeds produced by the population were also influenced by rainfall. The number of seeds produced per plant ranged from 24-1675. The latter value is similar to or greater than that recorded in many other annual species. Less than half the viable seeds in the soil germinate in any one year and a substantial proportion of seeds survive from one year to the next. E. gallicum persists in the quarry through a suite of traits including high seed output by those plants that survive to reproduce, germination by a small proportion of the seeds in the seed bank in any one year, and viability of seeds that remain in the soil for at least 1 yr.-from Authors

dc:title: Use of visual cover assessments as quantitative estimators of some British woodland taxa.
dc:creator: Sykes J.
dc:description: Ten observers made visual estimates of plant cover on a series of 4 m2, 50 m2 and 200 m2 quadrats in a woodland. Mean cover values from the ten observers corresponded reasonably closely with point quadrat estimates of cover for most species in the 4 m2 quadrats. For all taxa, significant differences occurred between the estimates of different observers at all quadrat sizes. Using an observer drawn at random, 90% confidence intervals were in the range + or - 10-20% cover. The corresponding range for an individual repeating an estimate on the same quadrat was + or - 5-15% cover. Variability between observers was usually lowest when estimating broad-leaved species and highest with fine-leaved species and bryophytes. Observers differed in the consistency with which they tended to under- or over-estimate cover in relation both to species and to quadrat size; this consistency was not correlated with experience. Use of mean bias correction factors brought about clear gains in the precision or cover estimates for most species. -from Authors

dc:title: Demography of Floerkea proserpinacoides, a forest floor annual. II. Density-dependent reproduction.
dc:creator: Smith B.
dc:description: Floerkea proserpinacoides (Limnanthaceae) is an autogamous, spring ephemeral forest annual. The number of seeds produced by a plant is determined by the number of flowers a plant produces, the proportion of flowers that successfully set seed ("flower survival'), and the number of seeds set per successful fruit. All three decreased as density increased. Mean fecundity was low regardless of density; plants at non-competitive densities produced a mean of only 12 seeds. The rate of flower production was reduced earlier at high density through reductions in the number of flower-bearing nodes produced by vegetative buds. Flowers that were produced early in the season survived better and produced more seeds per fruit than those produced just before the tree canopy closed and light flux decreased. Both flower survival and seed set per fruit were reduced earlier at high density. -from Author Limnanthaceae.

dc:title: The growth of Sphagnum: experiments on, and simulation of, some effects of light flux and water-table depth.
dc:creator: Hayward P.
dc:description: Growth of Sphagnum capillifolium (hummocks), S. papillosum (lawns) and S. recurvum (pools and flushed lawns) was studied. Water-table depth had little effect on growth measured as increase of dry matter; shading reduced growth and there were specific differences associated with plant size. There were no significant interactions between water-table depth ahd shading. For growth measured as growth in length, there were highly significant interactions, individual species behaving differently in response to shade and, to a lesser extent, in response to water-table depth. In Sphagnum lawns in 2 natural habitats there was a negative correlation between depth of the water-table and surface- roughness. In experimental conditions surface-roughness increased both as the water-table was raised and as shade increased. A computer simulation of growth of Sphagnum in a lawn was able to reproduce the observed variations in surface roughness. In mixed lawns of 2 species, the one in its 'natural' habitat out-grew the other.-from Authors Sphagnum capillifolium Sphagnum papillosum Sphagnum recurvum.

dc:title: Effect of water-table depth on shoot growth, root growth, and nodulation of Myrica gale seedlings.
dc:creator: Schwintzer C.R.
dc:description: The considerable phenotypic plasticity in response to moisture and aeration exhibited by Myrica gale, an actinorhizal dinitrogen-fixing shrub, appears to be a valuable adaptation in its natural habitat where the water level often fluctuates. -from Authors

dc:title: 'Falling apart' as a lifestyle: the rhizome architecture and population growth of Salvinia molesta.
dc:creator: Room P.
dc:description: Ramets bore up to three ranks of side branches and the degree of branching was positively correlated with concentration of nutrients in the ambient water. Branching was not correlated with the degree of crowding. Rhizomes from infertile water were tough; most contained no 2nd or 3rd rank side branches. Their oldest ramets were senescent and had a mean age or 12 ramet generations. These rhizomes appeared to fragment when their oldest segments degenerated. Rhizomes from fertile water were brittle, most contained 3 ranks of side branches. Their oldest ramets were not senescent and had a mean age of 7 ramet generations. These rhizomes appeared to fragment when repeated branching forced segments to bend beyond the limits of their elasticity. Fitness appeared to be maximized in infertile water by the retention of senescing ramets so that the nutrients they contained could be reallocated within colonies and in fertile water by rapid proliferation of small colonies which could act as dispersal units. Rhizome architecture could not be explained as an optimal solution to the problem of tesselating a plane to maximize light utilization. A model of branching growth was found to give a good description of increase in the population of ramets under conditions optimal for branching. -from Author

dc:title: Persistence of habitat dominance in the annual Impatiens capensis ( Balsaminaceae).
dc:creator: Winsor J.
dc:description: Seedling emergence in the field was earlier and occurred over a shorter period in Impatiens capensis than in the perennial species Eupatorium maculatum and Urtica dioica, both in shade and in full sunlight. The sequence of emergence was explained by differential response to temperature. Impatiens capensis had its maximum germination at temperatures as low as 5oC, but E. maculatum and U. dioica occurred only at higher temperatures. Germination of E. maculatum was greatly enhanced by temperatures cycling between 5 and 15oC. Growth rates of I. capensis were less suppressed by the low temperatures prevailing during seedling emergence than were those of E. maculatum and U. dioica. Urtica dioica grown from seed failed to become established in I. capensis stands, but previously established U. dioica plants, transplanted to I. capensis stands, grew and sometimes set seed. The mechanism for persistence of I. capensis includes development of a light-blocking canopy of even-aged individuals. -from Author

dc:title: Three radiocarbon-dated pollen diagrams from upland peats north- west of Merthyr Tydfil, South Wales.
dc:creator: Chambers F.
dc:description: Peat growth began in the basin at c7000 yr BP. This is before a rather late Boreal-Atlantic transition at this site, for Alnus was slow to immigrate into this upland region. The base status of the basin was then significantly higher than the present day and the mire supported a wide range of fen species. There is some evidence for Mesolithic and Neolithic interference, but the major impact upon forest was in the Bronze Age. Peat initiation at the moisture-shedding sites dates from the Early Medieval, notwithstanding considerable differences in peat depth between the sites. Peat growth here began under Callunetum. The present dominance of Molinia is a recent feature and post-dates the start of the Industrial Revolution. -from Author

dc:title: Ecological studies in four contrasting lowland rain forests in Gunung Mulu National Park, Sarawak III. Decomposition processes and nutrient losses from leaf litter.
dc:creator: Anderson J.
dc:description: Measurements of soil respiration, leaf litter decomposition and litterfall-standing crop quotients were made during 1 yr in alluvial forest, dipterocarp forest and heath forest. Comparative studies were also made in forest over limestone over a 6-month period. Soil respiration mainly represents CO2 efflux from the surface litter layers and the root mat. -from Authors

dc:title: Optimal life-history characteristics and vegetative demography in Eriophorum vaginatum.
dc:creator: Fetcher N.
dc:description: One model predicted the optimal age of first production of daughter tillers, where the optimum is defined as the age of first tillering that maximizes the rate of population growth when the population acquires a stable age distribution. The predicted age was 4.5 yr. The observed distribution of ages at which daughter tillers were produced has a peak at 4 yr. Because most tillers of E. vaginatum <5 yr old are producing daughters for the first time, results appear to support the model. Survival costs of tillering were estimated by dividing the change in age-specific survival rate by the change in age-specific tillering rate. A 2nd model predicted that such costs would increase with age. This prediction was also supported. -from Author

dc:title: Vegetation, nutrients and agricultural land use in a north Buckinghamshire valley fen.
dc:creator: Wheeler B.D.
dc:description: Concentrations of dissolved inorganic N, soluble reactive P and K were generally higher in fen water from parts of the mire dominated by Epilobium hirsutum (below an arable field) than in fen meadow areas dominated by Juncus subnodulosus (below pasture). Concentrations of N, P and K in substratum extracts were also greater. The biomass and net productivity of the vegetation were greater in the fen below the arable field than below the pasture. Part of an enclosure erected in part of the fen meadow site rapidly became invaded by E. hirsutum to produce a vegetation floristically similar to that below the arable field, though of lower biomass and net productivity. Accessibility to grazing animals (mainly cattle) , not nutrient supply, is therefore considered the main cause of the differentiation of the vegetation cover in these mires. The importance of management in maintaining species-rich fen vegetation is obvious. -from Author

dc:title: Compensatory production in Solanum carolinense following attack by a host-specific herbivore.
dc:creator: Solomon B.P.
dc:description: Studied the effect of infestation of Solanum carolinense by Frumenta nundinella. Leaf and fruit infestation reduced fruit production and total net production (in energy units) of plants allowed to grow for 9 wk after infestation. Net production and fruit production of plants allowed to grow for 13 wk were not significantly different from that of controls. No organ on infested plants (except fruits) differed in specific energy or N concentration from its counterpart on control plants; infested fruits had lower specific energy than non-infested fruits. The cost to the plant of producing an infested fruit (in terms of energy and of N) was approximately equal to the cost of producing a seeded fruit.-from Author

dc:title: The distribution of plants in limestone pavement: tests of species interaction and niche separation against null hypotheses.
dc:creator: Silvertown J.
dc:description: The vascular plants of limestone pavements occur in discrete compartments (grikes) which give clear limits to possible niches. Tests of species distribution against null models show that some significant deviations from random distribution occur. A comparison of niche overlap, an analysis of species association and an analysis of sympatric v. allopatric plant distribution all suggest that competitive exclusion and niche separation are not important phenomena in this habitat.-from Author

dc:title: Experimental ecology of Dryas octopetala ecotypes. II. A demographic model of growth, branching and fecundity.
dc:creator: McGraw J.
dc:description: A general model of plant growth, branching, and seed production simulates plant growth by considering the plant to be an assemblage of repeated units (modules). A shoot module (a meristem and associated live leaves) passes through growth, branching and flowering stages governed by size-dependent transition probabilities. Lefkovitch matrices formed from these transition probabilities are used to project shoot-module population size, and therefore plant growth. Model parameters were calculated for 2 ecotypes of Dryas octopetala. Shoot-module size categories were defined by leaf area. Censuses revealed size-dependent growth, branching and flowering patterns for both ecotypes. Rates of new shoot production increased with shoot size as did the proportion of flowering vs. branching shoots. Contrasting patterns of allocation of materials for the 2 ecotypes maintained positive and comparable rates of vegetative growth for natural populations found in different habitats in the field. Shoot population growth was most sensitive to annual growth increments, especially of small shoots and less sensitive to the rate at which shoots produced 'offspring' shoots. Growth was relatively insensitive to the proportion of shoots which flowered (rather than branched), the number of offspring shoots produced per branching shoot and the number of offspring shoots produced per flowering shoot.-from Authors

dc:title: Elements returned to forest floor in two rainforest and three plantation plots in tropical Australia.
dc:creator: Brasell H.M.
dc:description: Returns of K, Ca, Mg and Na to the forest floor in rainfall, throughfall, litterfall and branchfall were compared for tropical rainforest and adjacent plantations of Araucaria cunninghamii at 2 sites with contrasting rainfall and soil fertility. At one site a plantation of Flindersia brayleyana was also compared. At each site, K input was highest in the rainforest plots. Addition of Na was higher at a wetter site, and was mostly derived from rainfall. Estimates of the loss of dry weight and elements from the litter layer, were greater in the rainforest plots than in the Araucaria plantations. The annual rate of litter disappearance (k, the quotient of the annual litterfall to the mean amount of litter on the forest floor) ranged from 0.69 for the Araucaria plot to 1.25 for the rainforest plot at the same site. -from Authors

dc:title: Secondary succession following slash and burn agriculture in north-eastern India. I. Biomass, litterfall and productivity.
dc:creator: Toky O.
dc:description: The early colonizers varied depending upon the type of vegetation before farming and the seed and rhizome sources in the soil, and these depended largely on the agricultural practices. Initially, weeds predominated, but a bamboo (Dendrocalamus hamiltonii) was an important component of 10-20-yr old fallow; later this was replaced by shade-intolerant trees. Old-field succession was accompanied by increased species diversity, reduced dominance, and increased above-ground net primary productivity which reached 1.8 kg m- 2 yr-1 in a 20-yr old fallow. Above-ground biomass increased linearly with age up to 15 kg m-2 in a 20-yr old fallow. Rate of accumulation of biomass increased for 15 yr, when it was 0.9 kg m-2 yr-1, then declined slightly. Litterfall increased with the age of the fallow up to 1.0 kg m-2 yr-1 in a 20-yr fallow. -from Authors

dc:title: Effects of added nutrients on the vegetation of two coastal grasslands in the dry-zone of Sri Lanka.
dc:creator: Pemadasa M.A.
dc:description: Turves given complete nutrient solution and no extra K grew equally well and much better than those given no P, which in turn grew better than the turves given no N and distilled water only. Increasing concentrations of both nitrate and phosphate increased the growth progressively. In dry pasture much of the benefit of the added nutrients was shared by the two predominant species Eragrostis tenella and Zoysia matrella, which grew vigorously and luxuriantly, suppressing the other species including Cynodon dactylon. In damp pasture, however, the augmented nutrient regimes improved the growth of C. dactylon substantially. The restricted growth and low productivity of the 2 grasslands are related chiefly to the limited effects of low concentrations of N and P.-from Author
